body_html:
That seems to do the trick for me. The point of confusion was that Mac nightlys in conda appear to have moved from being named pytorch-nightly to pytorch-nightly-cpu. So if one does conda install pytorch-nightly -c pytorch, you get a build from 9/29, the most recent one that was named that way.

The correct way to do it is now conda install pytorch-nightly-cpu -c pytorch. Docs need to be updated here: https://pytorch.org/get-started/locally/

That seems to do the trick for me. The point of confusion was that Mac nightlys in conda appear to have moved from being named pytorch-nightly to pytorch-nightly-cpu. So if one does conda install pytorch-nightly -c pytorch, you get a build from 9/29, the most recent one that was named that way.
The correct way to do it is now conda install pytorch-nightly-cpu -c pytorch. Docs need to be updated here: https://pytorch.org/get-started/locally/
body:
That seems to do the trick for me. The point of confusion was that Mac nightlys in conda appear to have moved from being named `pytorch-nightly` to `pytorch-nightly-cpu`. So if one does `conda install pytorch-nightly -c pytorch`, you get a build from 9/29, the most recent one that was named that way.

The correct way to do it is now `conda install pytorch-nightly-cpu -c pytorch`. Docs need to be updated here: https://pytorch.org/get-started/locally/
